PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. Mildred (Hodgson) Knight
Address: Invermorth, Sask.
Birthplace: Worcester, Massachusetts, U.S.A.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1911 (approx.)
Where did you set up housekeeping? Invermorth, Sask. (new freight sale)
Where had you been living before that? Boston, Mass.
For how many people did you prepare meals? Eight
How far was it to your nearest store? Eight
How often could a visit be made to the store? Every three weeks
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, sugar, baking powder, lard, butter (when not making it), condensed milk

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Don't remember
In what quantities did you buy it? 50 lb.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? Don't know
How much did you use graham flour? No
Whole wheat flour? No
Was flour milled locally? Yes. How far away? 12 mi. What year? 1911-12
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? No
What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal? A little. Whole Wheat? No. Farina? None
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? Food chopper

Partridge Pie

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

- Few canned foods
- More use of dried fruit in winter
- Wild fruits canned at home
- Dried beans
- More game birds & animals

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homemade and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Around 1921 when my husband and I took over the store.
